text:
Consult NotePt: Ulysses Ogrady MC #0937884Date: 07/01/19 Williams Ct M OSCAR, JOHNNY Hyderabad, WI 62297
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 77-year-old-woman with long standing hypertension who presented as a Walk-in to me at the Brigham Health Center on Friday. Recently had been started q.o.d. on Clonidine since 01/15/19 to taper off of the drug. Was told to start Zestril 20 mg. q.d. again. The patient was sent to the Unit for direct admission for cardioversion and anticoagulation, with the Cardiologist, Dr. Wilson to follow.
SOCIAL HISTORY: Lives alone, has one daughter living in Nantucket. Is a non-smoker, and does not drink alcohol. 
 HOSPITAL COURSE AND TREATMENT: During admission, the patient was seen by Cardiology, Dr. Wilson, was started on IV Heparin, Sotalol 40 mg PO b.i.d. increased to 80 mg b.i.d., and had an echocardiogram. By 07-22-19 the patient had better rate control and blood pressure control but remained in atrial fibrillation. On 08.03.19, the patient was felt to be medically stable.

text: Physician Discharge Summary Admit date: 10/12/1982 Discharge date: 10/22/1982 Patient Information Jack Smith, 54 y.o. male (DOB = 1/21/1928) Home Address: 123 Park Drive SAN DIEGO CA 03245 Home Phone: 764-212-9874 (home) What language do you prefer to use when discussing your healthcare?: English What language do you prefer for written communication?: English Type of Advance Care Directive(s): Health Care Proxy Care Plan Partner: wife Jessy Smith Code Status at Discharge: Full Code (Presumed) Discharge address same as facesheet: Yes Hospitalization Summary Principal Problem: Lumbar spinal stenosis Surgeries this Admission Past Procedures (to Today) Date Procedures Providers 10/19/1982 L4-L5 Revision Laminectomy. Items for Post-Hospitalization Follow-Up: Instructions After Your Patient's Lumbar Spine Surgery * Please monitor temperature, heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate. * Please check the incision site to look for signs of infection including redness, swelling, and purulent drainage. * Remove the primary dressing on POD 7 if it remains clean and dry. The incision may then be left OTA if dry. * Arrange physical therapy, and occupational therapy. * Report to the physician if any of the listed warning signs occur. Pending Results Procedure Component Value Ref Range Date/Time FL Fluoroscopy More Than 1 Hour [203078398] Resulted: 10/22/1982 1525 Lab Status: In process Updated: 10/22/1982 1526 Hospital Course 54 yo patient with past medical history of diabetes, coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, diabetic neuropathy, tremor, underwent an elective L45 revision laminectomy and extension fusion on 10/19/1982 for spinal stenosis which failed conservative management. Patient underwent a L45 revision laminectomy and fusion extension on 10/19/1982 for spinal stenosis. The patient tolerated the procedure well and had an uncomplicated postoperative course, with exception of sustaining a fall during his admission. The patient fell landing onto his Rt hip with a head strike. The patient was observed and had no serious repercussions, or injuries from the fall. Standard care with IV Dilaudid for acute pain management, prophylactic IV antibiotics, and TEDS/P-boots for DVT prophylaxis. The patient was mobilized OOB WBAT with physical therapy beginning on POD 1. Refer to the page 3 for functional details. The wound was clean and healing at time of discharge. The patient was medically stable for transfer to rehab on POD 3. Medications Allergies: Niacin and Procainamide Prescriptions prior to admission Medication Sig • albuterol (PROVENTIL HFA;VENTOLIN HFA) 90 mcg/actuation inhaler Inhale 2 puffs into the lungs every 6 (six) hours as needed for shortness of breath. Directions: as needed for shortness of breath • amiodarone (PACERONE) 200 MG tablet Take 1 tablet (200 mg total) by mouth daily. • aspirin 81 mg chewable tablet Take 81 mg by mouth daily. • atorvastatin (LIPITOR) 40 MG tablet Take 1 tablet (40 mg total) by mouth daily. • cyanocobalamin, vitamin B-12, 2,500 mcg sublingual tablet Place 2,500 mcg under the tongue daily. • melatonin 5 mg Tab Take 1 tablet (5 mg total) by mouth nightly. Take 1-2 hours prior to bedtime • metFORMIN (GLUCOPHAGE) 500 MG tablet Take 500 mg by mouth daily with breakfast. • metoprolol succinate (TOPROL-XL) 25 MG 24 hr tablet Take 1 tablet (25 mg total) by mouth daily. • PARoxetine (PAXIL) 40 MG tablet Take 40 mg by mouth every morning. • primidone (MYSOLINE) 50 MG tablet 1 tab tid (Patient taking differently: Take 50 mg by mouth 2 (two) times a day. 1 tab tid Indications: tremors) • tiotropium (SPIRIVA HANDIHALER) 18 mcg inhalation capsule Inhale 1 capsule (18 mcg total) into the lungs daily. • acetaminophen (TYLENOL) 500 MG tablet Take 650 mg by mouth as directed. Directions: Not available • amoxicillin (AMOXIL) 500 MG capsule TAKE 4 CAPSULES (2,000 MG TOTAL) ONE TIME FOR 1 DOSE. (SUBSTITUTED FOR AMOXIL) • metFORMIN (GLUCOPHAGE) 1000 MG tablet Take 1,000 mg by mouth daily with dinner. • nitroglycerin (NITROSTAT) 0.3 MG SL tablet Place 0.3 mg under the tongue every 5 (five) minutes as needed for chest pain. repeat x3 • omeprazole (PRILOSEC) 20 MG capsule Take 20 mg by mouth daily.
